ğŸ Installation and Conda EnvironmentÂ¶

This package requires Python 3.8+

Option 1: pipÂ¶

Note: â€œherbieâ€ is already registered on PyPI, so I continue to use the â€œhrrrbâ€ package to publish for now. This may change in version 0.1.0

Install the last published version from PyPI.

pip install hrrrb

The version on PyPI has likely diverged a lot from the code on GitHub, so I would recommend not getting from PyPI. To get the most recent Herbie code, you may install the package directly from GitHub.

pip install git+https://github.com/blaylockbk/HRRR_archive_download.git

Requires: curl, requests, pandas, xarray, cfgrib Optional: matplotlib, cartopy, Carpenter_Workshop

Option 2: condaÂ¶

If conda environments are new to you, I suggest you become familiar with managing conda environments.

I have provided a sample Anaconda environment.yml file that lists the minimum packages required plus some extras that might be useful when working with other types of weather data. Look at the bottom lines of that yaml fileâ€¦there are two ways to install hrrrb with pip within the environment file. Comment out the line you donâ€™t want.

For the latest development code:

- pip:
    - git+https://github.com/blaylockbk/HRRR_archive_download.git

For the latest published version

- pip:
    - hrrrb

First, create the virtual environment with

conda env create -f environment.yml

Then, activate the herbie environment. Donâ€™t confuse this conda environment name with the package name.

conda activate herbie

Occasionally, you might want to update all the packages in the environment.

conda env update -f environment.yml

Alternative â€œInstallâ€ MethodÂ¶

There are several other ways to â€œinstallâ€ a python package so you can import them. One alternatively is you can clone the repository.

git clone https://github.com/blaylockbk/HRRR_archive_download.git

To import the package, you will need to update your PYTHONPATH environment variable to find the directory you put this package or add the line sys.path.append("/path/to/herbie") at the top of your python script.
